newsitem.title: BELGIUM: Oilseeds industry attacks EU area aid plans.
newsitem.headline: Oilseeds industry attacks EU area aid plans.

text.p: European Commission draft plans to pay a single non-crop specific area aid payment would be disastrous for the oilseeds sector, European oilseed producers said.
"It appears to be absolutely ridiculous," said an official at the EU Seed Crushers and Oil Processors Federation (FEDIOL).
The official, who cautioned that he had not seen the draft, added that it could lead to a massive switch into cereals and sharp rise in grain surpluses.
"It would end oilseeds output in Europe," the official said.

The payment would be a base of 66 Ecus a tonne multiplied by regional cereals reference yields fixed under the 1992 reform of the Common Agricultural Policy (CAP). It would represent a massive cut in oilseed aid but a 12 Ecus a tonne increase for cereals.
Oilseeds area aids have traditionally been set 2.1 times higher than cereals aids to take account of of lower yields and more difficult growing conditions.
The average EU rapeseed yield is around 2.5 tonnes per hectare, compared with six tonnes for soft wheat and eight tonnes for maize.
The EU is a large net oilseeds importer.
The draft plans, due to be adopted on Tuesday, are part of a package of farm reform proposals to prepare for the EU's expansion eastwards after 2000.
Detailed plans, which would be examined by EU farm ministers, are not expected until the autumn. --Peter Blackburn Brussels newsroom 322 287 6830
